current-chamber.#text: IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES

official-title.#text:
To improve student academic achievement in science,
		  technology, engineering, and mathematics subjects.

committee-name.#text:
Committee on Health, Education, Labor,
			 and Pensions

cosponsor.#tail:
) introduced the following
			 bill; which was read twice and referred to the

short-title.#text:
STEM Education for the Global Economy
			 Act of 2013

text.#text: This part may be cited as the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: and inserting the following:
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965/t:II/pt:B

text.#text: The

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: is amended by striking

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
Elementary and
			 Secondary Education Act of 1965
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965
usc/20/6301/etseq

text.#text:
The purpose of this part is to improve
				student academic achievement in science, technology, engineering, and
				mathematics subjects (referred to in this part as

improving instruction in such subjects in
				preschool through grade 12;

improving student engagement in, and
				increasing student access to, courses in such subjects;

improving the
				quality and effectiveness of classroom instruction by recruiting, training, and
				supporting highly effective teachers and providing robust tools and supports
				for students and teachers in such subjects;

closing student
				achievement gaps, and preparing more students from groups traditionally
				underrepresented in STEM subjects to enter and succeed in postsecondary
				education and careers, in such subjects;

increasing access
				to quality after school programs; and

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965/s:2204

text.#text:
recognizing that
				STEM subjects are diverse subject areas and that STEM subject programs must
				expose students to content and skills in a host of constantly changing and
				evolving STEM subject content areas, as specifically identified by each State
				or eligible entity in
In this part:
The term

a State
				educational agency; or

a State
				educational agency in partnership with—

another State
				educational agency; or

a consortium of
				State educational agencies.
The term

a high-need local
				educational agency;

a consortium of
				high-need local educational agencies.

quote.#tail:
means an entity
				that has expertise and a demonstrated record of success in improving student
				learning and engagement in the identified subjects described in

A nonprofit
				organization with a demonstrated record of success in improving student
				learning in STEM subjects, including educational and teacher-focused
				organizations, professional societies, museums and after school and informal
				learning organizations, and community-based and cultural organizations.

A
				business.

A STEM faculty or
				teacher training department of an institution of higher education.

An educational
				service agency.

Another
				appropriate entity.

The

any of the 50

the District of

means the subjects
				of science, technology, engineering, and mathematics, including other academic
				subjects that build on these disciplines, such as computer science, and other
				academic subjects that a State identifies as important to the workforce of the
				State.

text.#text:
A State or eligible entity that submits a request to use
				the additional State activities reservation described in

Each State or eligible entity that receives a grant
				under this part shall use the grant funds to carry out each of the following
				activities:

Increasing access
				for students in preschool through grade 12 that belong to groups that are
				traditionally underrepresented in STEM subject fields (including female
				students, minority students, students who are limited English proficient,
				students who are children with disabilities, and students from low-income
				families) to high-quality courses in the identified subjects.

Implementing
				evidence-based programs of instruction based on high-quality standards and
				assessments in the identified subjects.

Providing
				professional development and other comprehensive systems of support for
				teachers and school leaders to promote high-quality instruction and
				instructional leadership in the identified subjects.

Providing
				technical assistance to subgrantees and other high-need schools and local
				educational agencies in order to improve student achievement and narrow
				achievement gaps in identified subjects, including through—

the development
				and implementation of multi-tiered systems of support; and

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: section 103 of the Higher Education Act of 1965
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Higher Education Act of 1965/s:103

text.#text:
the development
				of curricula consistent with the principals of universal design for learning as

Providing
				equipment and materials to support experiential learning activities in STEM
				subjects.

Each State or eligible entity that receives a grant
				under this part may use the grant funds to carry out 1 or more of the following
				activities:

Recruiting
				qualified teachers and instructional leaders who are trained in identified
				subjects, including teachers who have transitioned into the teaching profession
				from a career in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics
				fields.

Providing
				induction and mentoring services to new teachers in identified subjects.

Providing
				opportunities for teachers to partner with after school program providers to
				offer hands-on engaging STEM programming that complements and supplements the
				school day.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
,
				and may include Internet-based curricula and Internet-based instructional

Each State or eligible entity that receives a grant under
				this part shall award subgrants, on a competitive basis, to eligible
				subgrantees.

A State or eligible entity shall award subgrants under
				this subsection that are of sufficient size and scope to support high-quality,
				evidence-based, effective programs that are consistent with the purpose of this
				part.

Each eligible subgrantee desiring a subgrant under this
				subsection shall submit an application to the State or eligible entity at such

text.#text: From the funds reserved under

term.#tail: (referred to in this section as the

text.#text: The term

operated by 1 or
				more State educational agencies, or a consortium of local educational agencies,
				acting in partnership with 1 or more outside partners that have a demonstrated
				record of success in improving the effectiveness of science, technology,
				engineering, and mathematics teachers or increasing the retention of such
				teachers;

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
), as members of the corps,
				that constitutes not less than 5 percent and not more than 10 percent of
				elementary school, middle school, and high school teachers who teach science,
				technology, engineering, and mathematics subjects and who—
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965/s:2208/ss:b/p:1

text.#text:
that selects a
				group of highly rated teachers (through a process, and for a duration,
				determined by the entity described in

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: ; or
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965/s:2208/ss:b/p:1

text.#text:
teach in a
				participating high-need school in the region served by the entity described in

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: if accepted as a member of the corps; and
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965/s:2208/ss:b/p:1

text.#text:
agree to teach in
				a participating high-need school in the region served by the entity described
				in

that aims to
				attract, improve, and retain teachers who teach science, technology,
				engineering, and mathematics subjects and to increase student achievement in
				such subjects, including by—

providing
				instructional leadership responsibilities for corps members in their schools,
				local educational agencies, or States, such as mentoring beginning science,
				technology, engineering, and mathematics teachers and leading professional
				development activities for teachers not participating in the corps;

providing corps
				members with research-based professional development on instructional
				leadership and effective teaching methods for science, technology, engineering,
				and mathematics subjects;

providing each
				teacher who is a corps member with a salary supplement of not less than $10,000
				per year, in recognition of such teacher’s teaching accomplishments,
				leadership, and increased responsibilities, for each year such teacher serves
				as a member of the corps; and

building a
				community of practice among corps members to enable such members to network,
				collaborate, and to share best practices and resources with each other.

Grants awarded under this section shall be for a period
				of not more than 3 years.

Funds received
				under this part shall be used to supplement, and not supplant, funds that would

A State that
				receives funds under this part for a fiscal year shall maintain the fiscal
				effort provided by the State for the subjects supported by the funds under this
				part at a level equal to or greater than the level of such fiscal effort for
				the preceding fiscal year.
